I've got my stave paper. now what? thanks for the info and the time you've put into the answer. it's greatly appreciated

ok, so let's make some empty bars (measures.) draw some vertical lines through the staff like (ref: bars.png)this. those are called bar lines. they separate the bars (measures.) it's like walls, separating the rooms. in my example i have made 8 bars (or 8 measures). each bar will have notes, etc, in it. each bar will have 4 beats worth of music in it (as i mentioned before, most music uses 4 beats per bar. in some cases 3, or even weirder numbers, but most music uses 4). let me know when you are ready to start putting notes, etc, in the bars. just to be clear, the notes will go in between the vertical lines you just drew, and they will go amongst the horizontal lines, occasionally popping out above or below the stack of horizontal lines. the vertical lines are to divide one bar from the next. ok let me know when you are cool with this

okay I learned beats, what's the next step?

most music uses beats in groups of 4. (1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4, etc). listen to some songs and find the beat like you did before, but instead of counting them all the same, see if you can count them in groups of 4, and see if you can easily find where the "1" is. these groups of 4 are called Measures (or more commonly called "Bars"). every 4 beats (1, 2, 3, 4) makes up a bar. a bar is a unit of time which is 4 beats long. Most songs use 4 beats per bar. some songs use 3 (or even other numbers in rare cases) but usually 4. See if you can find the beats and bars in some of your favorite songs. then the next step is to get some staff paper and i will tell you how rhythms work. actually you can do rhythms without staff paper but if you want to learn to read you are going to eventually have to get staff paper. ok let me know when you are ready for the next step

how do you feel about pirating music? Not yours but in general

copies are not really worth anything. anyone can make a copy of a file on a computer, and share it with a friend. this is free. the only copy of a song that you can really charge for is the original, because if the artist doesn't release the original, then no one will ever hear it. so the original really has the highest value, and the creator can charge any price for it, and if that price is not paid then the song will never be released. but once it is released, it would be hard to sell copies, because anyone can make a copy for free. so any company that is trying to sell you copies of a song (basically any copy after the original) really cannot expect to make money. unless they have some kind of police force to stop people from sharing files with their friends

So with the Dec. 1 deadline, would you say your progress (both for the video and compared to the Japan video) is increasing exponentially?

it increased a lot after oct 15, which is when i established the dec1 deadline, but since then i have pretty much maxed out. i am still setting timers and making minute by minute goals which are attempting to push it tigher, 1min20 seconds (on graphics) per day is about the most i think is possible, that's my grand record, on a full day. but i am still trying to beat that. in order to meet dec1, i pretty much have to be done with the graphics by this thursday (which would entail doing about 4min per day at this point) and even if i did that, i would still have to absolutely crush the rest, at unprecedented levels. still have to record the final narration, and final vocals for all jingles (which mostly has dense 4 part harmonies, as you know. and there's 66 jingles) and do the score, which probably takes the longest out of those 3 things. very important, i wish i could let you hear what history of japan sounded like with only narration and jingles and no underscored music (it is very boring, the underscore has huge effect on the video, that's why i underscore all my own music, moment by moment). Everything after graphics (score, jingles, narration, labels, troubleshoot, etc etc) for history of japan took a total of 30 days. so even if i finish graphics by thursday (wildly impossible) i would have to complete what was 30 days (for a 9 min vid) in 13 days (for a 19 min vid.) so basically that would require more than a 4x speed improvement from what i was doing in dec/jan last year on japan. but, graphics so far has generally been running at 2x speed from last year. i don't know how that's possible. maybe because i'm not trying to make vines every day? not really sure how to account for it, but i guess i have more experience now
